data.title: Workaround for NRE on linux
data.body: Fixes #2416

data.title: Always use the native platform for OpenTK
data.body: This fixes #2416 by preventing SDL2 from being used in OpenTK.

data.title: Tidying up using statements
data.body:
As mentioned by @flibitijibibo in #2218, we have some unnecessary using statements left over from before the file splits.
I've gone through and tidied them up (I may have gone a bit overboard in finding them).

As I was looking at all the split files, I also did some very minor code tidy ups:
OpenTKGamePlatform.cs - Moved Linux OnIsMouseVisibleChanged beside the windows one.
RenderTarget2D.DirectX.cs - Removed an early return that wasn't doing anything.
Texture.OpenGL.cs - Removed setting variable to default, using this when not needed.
VertexDeclaration.OpenGL.cs - Use a using to rename a type to make the code the same in OpenGL/GLES

data.title: NullReferenceException when OpenGL Window on Linux is created
data.body:
I just upgraded to the latest version of MonoGame, and I now get a NullReferenceException inside OpenTK on Linux.  Line 326 of OpenTKGameWindow.cs

Full stack trace:

```
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object
  at OpenTK.NativeWindow..ctor (Int32 width, Int32 height, System.String title, GameWindowFlags options, OpenTK.Graphics.GraphicsMode mode, OpenTK.DisplayDevice device) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenTK.GameWindow..ctor (Int32 width, Int32 height, OpenTK.Graphics.GraphicsMode mode, System.String title, GameWindowFlags options, OpenTK.DisplayDevice device, Int32 major, Int32 minor, GraphicsContextFlags flags, IGraphicsContext sharedContext) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenTK.GameWindow..ctor (Int32 width, Int32 height, OpenTK.Graphics.GraphicsMode mode, System.String title, GameWindowFlags options, OpenTK.DisplayDevice device, Int32 major, Int32 minor, GraphicsContextFlags flags) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0

  at OpenTK.GameWindow..ctor () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0

  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamePlatform.Create (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game game) [0x00002] in /home/james/Projects/Redpoint/Tychaia/Protogame/ThirdParty/MonoGame/MonoGame.Framework/GamePlatform.cs:98

  at Protogame.CoreGame`2[Tychaia.TitleWorld,Tychaia.TychaiaWorldManager]..ctor (IKernel kernel) [0x00006] in /home/james/Projects/Redpoint/Tychaia/Protogame/Protogame/CoreGame.cs:98

exception inside UnhandledException handler: Thread creation failed.
```

data.title: Cache GetUniformLocation on a per shader basis
data.body:
Use ShaderProgram (was ShaderProgramInfo) more instead of just passing the int around.

Tested (on a very simple app) on WindowsGL and IOS.

Should still compile for PSM, we'll see what the build bot has to say.

Fixes #2218

data.title: Dispose Refactor
data.body:
This is a refactor of the dispose pattern across all the `GraphicsResource` objects.

The main change is the replacement of the `PlatformDispose()` with the normal virtual `Dispose(bool)` method.  This caused problems in heavily overloaded classes like Texture/Texture2D/RenderTarget2D where it was not possible for all three classes to have their own dispose implementations.  By only depending on `Dispose(bool)` any class can overload the disposal behavior.

The rest was just fixes to where dispose was not implemented under DirectX.  This included `ConstantBuffer`, `DepthStencilState`, `RasterizerState`, `SamplerState`.

Note I fell into the old #2191 trap while working on this and backtracked to correct myself.  That is a separate issue that still needs to be addressed.

data.title: AllowAltF4 - bug fix
data.body: AllowAltF4 seems not worked completely correctly on WindowsDX platform - this would fix it and will equate its behaviour to WindowsGL version. Also this request added possibility to use Alt(ex -keyboardState.IsKeyDown(Keys.LeftAlt)) on WindowsDX.

data.title: Replace argument in RebuildMGFX.bat
data.body:
Replace argument from /DX11
to /Profile:DirectX_11

Probably related to #2346 or #2344

data.title: Impelement RenderTargetCube for OpenGL
data.body:
Implement the OpenGL version of RenderTargetCube.

See [RenderTargetCube.cs](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/RenderTargetCube.cs).

Should probably do the same platform abstraction as we have on RenderTarget2D.

data.title: Fix SoundEffectInstance Properties
data.body: The volume, pitch, and pan were not being set consistently across all platforms.  This ensures the set/get always works correctly regardless of what the platform implementations do.  Based on #2408.

data.title: Trying to convert shader using 2MGFX.
BUGFIX: SoundEffectInstance volume was not set internally.
data.body: Volume setter did not write current SoundEffectInstance volume to internal class variable.

data.title: Followup To #2104
data.body: Fixed the remaining uses of `$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)` as explained in #2104.

data.title: DirectX Video Player Implementation
data.body: This PR implements Video and VideoPlayer for Windows 8 Metro and Windows 8 Desktop. Let me know if you run into any issues.

data.title: Don't grab a copy of the render targets array just to check length.
data.body: Issue was pointed out by @EugenyN in #2360

data.title: Remove SaveStateMode
data.body: Fixes #2340

data.title: Remove USE_FARSEER blocks
data.body: Fixes #2399

data.title: Windows 8.1 and .NET 4.5.1
data.body:
In the process of updating to the latest version of SharpDX we ran into the issue of how to support Windows 8.1 moving forward.

Windows 8.1 shipped in October 2013... so its been out for 6 months now.  For Windows 8.1 features you need to build for the .NET 4.5.1 profile.  SharpDX seems to now only support Windows 8.1 and .NET 4.5.1.  The [Steam hardware survey](http://store.steampowered.com/hwsurvey/) shows Windows 8 at 10% and Windows 8.1 at 12%... so still evenly split.

So how we want to deal with this for MonoGame?  Should we support both Win8 and Win8.1 for a while?  Do we just not update to Win8.1 for now?

data.title: SetupGL is a misnomer in GraphicsDevice
data.body: With the refactor and use of PlatformSetup() and other platform specific methods, the SetupGL method in GraphicsDevice is a misnomer. The core GraphicsDevice needs a little refactoring to make it less GL-centric. Maybe SetupGL should be renamed to SetupViewport. It's private, so nobody should be impacted by this change.

data.title: MonoGame test runner fails due to use of absolute paths
Remove USE_FARSEER
data.body:
In the vector math classes there is a #if USE_FARSEER.  I don't know why it was there, but it was part of the first commit to GitHub.

I suspect whatever reason this was in there isn't relevant today.

data.title: WindowsGL & Linux: implement backbuffer color, depth, stencil, multisampling
data.body:
This PR implements supports for setting the correct OpenGL backbuffer format based on the selected `GraphicsDevice.PresentationParameters`. It also implements support for `PresentInterval`.

The involves two changes:
1. Context construction (foreground and background) is moved from `OpenTKGameWindow` to `GraphicsDevice.OpenGL`. This is required because:
   - `GraphicsDevice.PresentationParameters` are not yet available when the `GameWindow` is initialized 
   - both foreground and background contexts must have the same pixel format, or context sharing will fail
   - it is a good idea in general, because context construction is an extremely heavy operation (e.g. up to 1sec on my rmbp because it has to power up the discrete GPU) - non-graphical applications should not pay this cost.
2. The desired `PresentationParameters` are translated to OpenGL attributes and passed to the context constructor.

`PresentInterval.Immediate`, `One` and `Two` are mapped to OpenGL swap intervals of 0, 1 and 2, respectively (see [EXT_swap_control](http://www.opengl.org/registry/specs/EXT/swap_control.txt)). `PresentInterval.Default` is mapped to OpenGL swap interval -1, which enables adaptive vsync if [EXT_swap_control_tear](http://www.opengl.org/registry/specs/EXT/wgl_swap_control_tear.txt) is supported - if not, OpenTK falls back to regular vsync instead.

Note that this PR is for the backbuffer only (aka default framebuffer). It does not affect multisampling in RenderTexture2D.

data.title: Remove new VectorX usage in static (out VectorX) methods
data.body:
Change all VectorX static methods with `out VectorX` parameters to directly assign the fields rather than constructing new VectorXs.

`Vector3.Reflect` had the wrong spacing, fixed.
`Vector4` must have had wrong line endings, sorry.

Whitespace free diff (needed for `Vector4`)
https://github.com/danzel/MonoGame/commit/36b4c5edaf4417f80ac57270f0a7ba7e3fcfefc6?w=1

When doing this I had to be careful not to always just assign to the output object. In cases where we use one of the values to calculate another (use X to calculate Y), we must not change X until all of the calculations are done as the objects may be referencing the same object.

A good example of this is `Vector2.Transform`:
https://github.com/danzel/MonoGame/commit/36b4c5edaf4417f80ac57270f0a7ba7e3fcfefc6?w=1#diff-98c66ffb85bd2f51034c56bffda1119fL411
position and result could reference the same object, so we cannot assign result.X immediately or it would change the calculation of Y.
This is not normally necessary and leads to extra code, as such is only done when required.

Fixes #1611

data.title: Fix asset loading on the desktop
data.body:
This PR fixes an issue where `ContentManager` is passing an absolute path to `TitleContainer.OpenStream()`. This is not allowed - `OpenStream` only accepts relative paths.

This fix allows the test suite to run correctly on desktop platforms.

data.title: Give ModelMeshCollection/ModelBoneCollection custom Iterators
data.body:
These interators are `struct` so as to reduce garbage.

Implementation matches XNA as pointed out by @tomspilman
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.graphics.modelmeshcollection.getenumerator.aspx
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.graphics.modelbonecollection.getenumerator.aspx

Fixes #2360

Files have been whitespace tidied also (as I was rewriting most of them), so you may want to use the whitespace free diff:
https://github.com/danzel/MonoGame/compare/mono:develop...danzel:fix-1611?w=1

(Sorry for the incorrect branch name, was going to work on that next. Will do now!)

data.title: Remove ResourceType, nothing referenced it
data.body: Fixes #2391

data.title: Refactor AndroidGameWindow to inherit GameWindow
data.body:
This is the Android half of #1851

Biggest changes to Android:
- OrientationListener is now created by the GameWindow rather than the Activity, this seems like a better place to put it.
- AndroidGameWindows now contains a MonoGameAndroidGameView (Which implements AndroidGameView) rather than implementing it itself. The bits I feel should be in the AndroidGameView have been moved over (Touch, Key, Motion handling, Create/Destroy FrameBuffer, ISurfaceHolderCallback)
- The code that goes in your activity has changed as the GameWindow is no longer an android View (see 9766c809f6b918fef724e2b0bd1f510c3015d692, e71d6a0cf0c2fb97234e3bebf25a2d2660a188d8).
- #if ANDROID hacks have been reduced in Game, GamePlatform, TouchPanel, TouchPanelState

data.title: Disable the web platform from being generated by default
data.body: This "fixes" #2390 by preventing it from being generated by default.  The web platform is probably something that people will want to opt-in to anyway, so we don't necessarily want to add it back as a default again (especially since the Web platform triggers downloading and building JSIL).

data.title: Remove ResourceType.cs
data.body:
Remove the old XNA 3.1 ResourceType enum.

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/ResourceType.cs

data.title: Unable to build JSIL on Mac
data.body:
`mono ./Protobuild.exe` fails on Mac OS X. I was working fine ~2-3 weeks ago.

Looks like now the project depends on JSIL, and it fails to build. Full log here: http://pastebin.com/5NkeBuv7
